awd_titl_txt: The Formation and Impact of Nascent Globular Star Clusters
awd_abstract_narration:
Star formation is one of the most important processes in determining the properties of our Universe.  The formation of stars changes galaxies in a variety of ways.  For example, the density of massive stars affects how much material in a galaxy is blasted into intergalactic space.   The number of massive stars determines the abundance of heavy elements available to form complex molecules, including those that are the basis of life.  The mode of star formation that has the strongest impact on its environment takes place in "super star clusters" (SSCs).  These super star clusters pack thousands of violent massive stars into small volumes, and these dense regions of massive stars act as bombs in their host galaxies.  Over the last few decades we have gained a wealth of knowledge about super star clusters.  For example, it is now known that super star clusters were formed in large numbers at early times in the Universe.  It is also known that ancient super star clusters (called "globular clusters") are present in great numbers in the Universe today.  However, it is not yet known how these clusters form.  Nor is it known how their properties depend on the environment they are born in.  This project will use new capabilities of the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) and NSF's Very Large Array to advance our knowledge.  Observations with these facilities will enable the investigation of the environments in which super star cluster are formed.  The investigator will expand her education and outreach program, called "Dark Skies, Bright Kids."  The investigator will extend the program to rural communities in Southern Virginia.

Results from ALMA have provided tantalizing clues about the origin of super star clusters, including the first known example of a molecular precursor for such a cluster.  Follow-up observations are underway to constrain the physical conditions in the molecular cloud before stars have formed.  Additional ALMA observations of nascent SSCs (after the stars have formed) have revealed an apparent trend in molecular line strengths and ratios with respect to the evolutionary state of the cluster.  The main scientific goals of this program to be addressed with this program include the following:  (1) Identify additional molecular precursors to SSCs (increasing the sample size from one),  (2) Constrain the physical environments required to form super star clusters, (3) Quantify the star formation efficiencies of these extreme star-forming regions, and (4) Codify the relationship between molecular line strengths and ratios and cluster dynamics.  These results will provide templates to help interpret molecular line ratios from unresolved sources in the more distant universe.  The observations at radio, millimeter, and sub-millimeter wavelengths required to address these issues are already obtained, currently underway, and planned for proposals this year.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

por.por_cntn:
Summary:
We investigated the physical conditions involved in different modes of star formation, leveraging NSF facilities to advance our knowledge of the most extreme star formation events in the universe ? the creation of ?super star clusters?. Through this award, we also provided training to both graduate and undergraduate students and supported science interest and literacy in socio-economically disadvantaged communities.


Scientific Outputs:
This program contributed all or in part to 12 peer-reviewed publications and 13 posters presented at professional meetings. Key outputs include the following:


1)    Some of the most extreme modes of star formation in the universe takes place in ?super star clusters?. As part of this program, we used ALMA observations of the nearest major galaxy merger, the Antennae Galaxies, to probe the earliest stages of super star cluster evolution. In this study we were able to determine the physical properties of newly formed clusters. We found that half of the sources we studied appear to be gravitationally bound, which will impact their survival and longevity.


2)    Determining why stars form where they do, is at the core of understanding how star formation takes place throughout the universe. To this end, our investigation of the abnormally low star formation in the Magellanic Ridge provided important insight. We ruled out a hypothesis that the low star formation in this region was due to high kinetic energy in the gas, which might have been expected given the dynamical interaction taking place between the Large and Small Magellanic Clouds.


3)    Probing the physical conditions of star formation requires the use multiple emission lines, which can be misinterpreted if the physics is over-simplified. We created and tested software to make the analysis of complex molecular line data more efficient. We used this software to analyze molecular emission lines produce maps of a range of properties across star forming regions. We find that this fitting tool allows us to more directly probe the physical conditions of the gas and values that are less subject to the effects of optical depth and line-of-sight projection than previous methods.


4)    Constraining the efficiency with which stars forms is a critical component in understanding galaxy evolution. We investigated the efficiency of extreme star formation in the Antennae Galaxy system, finding that only a small fraction of young clusters in the Antennae Galaxy system appear to be formed with a star formation efficiency > 0.2, which indicates that the vast majority are not likely to remain bound. We were also able to determine the range of ages of which natal clusters lose their associated molecular gas.


5)    High spatial resolution is important to understanding the internal structure of star forming regions. Our ALMA observations with a resolution of ~0.1??(~10 pc) were able to constrain the structure of the "Firecracker" region and the physical conditions of the birth environment of a candidate proto-globular cluster. Using high angular resolution observations of Henize 2-10, we were able to disentangle individual clusters from aggregate complexes at different stages of evolution as identified at lower resolution.


6)    We do not yet understand how emission from various molecular lines is related to the evolutionary state of a star cluster.  Using our ALMA observations of the galaxy Henize 2-10, we found that the molecular line ratios of regions containing the natal star clusters are different from the line ratios observed for other regions; regions with thermal radio emission have line ratios that appear to be correlated with the evolutionary stage of the clusters. 


Personnel Training
Through the course of this award, we trained a one postdoctoral scholar, four graduate students and two undergraduate students in millimeter and radio science and techniques, providing in-depth experience with the tools and techniques necessary to carry out this science program. Junior members have been trained in proposal and paper writing, scientific analysis, and presentation skills.


Outreach
* We supported science literacy in disadvantaged communities through the Dark Skies Bright Kids program (directed by the PI), running both semester-long after school clubs and week-long summer camps, in addition to ?one-off? events and star-viewing parties.

* We polished the club activity write-ups (aligned with the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS)) and made publicly available on the website.

* COVID required a two-year shift to virtual activities, and entire structure and pedagogy of the program had to be retooled, and kits of materials assembled and sent to students; feedback from participants was glowing (with examples provided in previous annual reports for this program).

* We published a peer-reviewed paper (Hayes et al. 2019), in which we found that a 10% decrease in children drawing "stereotypical" scientists after taking part in the program.

* We worked with UVA to produce a very high-quality video on the Dark Skies Bright Kids program: https://news.virginia.edu/video/reaching-stars-uva-community



Last Modified: 02/07/2023
Modified by: Kelsey E Johnson
